thread.title: Avoid These 10 States if You Want Cheap Utility and Gas Bills
thread.title_full: Avoid These 10 States if You Want Cheap Utility and Gas Bills

title: Avoid These 10 States if You Want Cheap Utility and Gas Bills
text:
Avoid These 10 States if You Want Cheap Utility and Gas Bills Written by: Laurie Kulikowski 08/06/15 - 9:13 AM EDT 
NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- Depending on which state you live in, your monthly energy costs can vary widely. In some states they're nearly double those of others. 
About 7.3% of the average consumer's total annual income goes to energy costs, according to personal finance Web site WalletHub . 
Just because local energy prices may be lower, however, that doesn't always equate to lower costs. Consumption is a key determinant in the total amount of an energy bill. More Headlines Best Back-to-School Tablet Buying Guide for 2015 
"In areas such as Southern Louisiana, with scorching summer weather but cheap electricity, households still end up with higher out-of-pocket costs than those in energy-expensive Northern California, where the temperate climate keeps heating and cooling units idle most of the year," WalletHub said in a report ranking state energy costs . 
WalletHub compared the total monthly energy bills in each of the 50 states and the District of Columbia, examining consumption rates and prices of four energy types: electricity, natural gas, motor fuel and home heating oil. 
Here's the list of states with the highest average monthly energy costs. Keeping in mind, however, that average consumption played a big factor in the rankings. ( Click here to see the states with the lowest average monthly energy costs.) 
WalletHub sources: t he U.S. Energy Information Administration, the Federal Highway Administration, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and AAA's Daily Fuel Gauge Report. 

Average Monthly Energy Cost: $331 Electricity Cost: $145 Motor Fuel Cost: $144 Home Heating Oil Cost: 9 cents 
Georgia has a population of approximately 10 million, according to 2014 U.S. Census data. The median household income in Georgia for the five years through 2013 was $49,179, below the nation's average of $53,046. 
The state's unemployment rate for June was 6.1%, above the national average of 5.3%.
